comment: Smooth sweet and very good with dinner! Enjoyed each sip first wheat I've ever had and was good with great flavor

I found this to be delicious, with a great after 
taste.  It's been a while since I've had it though.
Sweetness from the wheat really comes through on the palate and finish.  A nice treat for those looking for something "different" or a getaway from bourbon and ryes.

Brought this home for Ryan from NAILE 2014. Sweet, yes. This is honey, vanilla and a little bit of sugar and yeast. Tastes a lot like my in-laws' French bread fresh out of the oven. But this is a loaf of bread that got lit. Faintly yeasty gives way to subtle oak. I hope this is what OYO tastes like in a few years after aging more properly. A damn fine whiskey, well representing the wheat whiskeys. Well worth the wait.

As I smelled the whiskey I had notes of oak and sweet vanilla toffee. At first taste the full notes of wheat come across the pallate. Very sweet in flavor that settles in and stays. The whiskey is a smooth, easy drinker that I could drink all night.

This is pretty good if you're looking for a change up to bourbon. Bananas Foster and vanilla on the nose. Palate is sweet, low spice, and smooth. You could probably convince someone that its non-alcoholic booze.
Light easy and distinctive wheat, but elegant and great drink
Sweet, lots of brown sugar, caramel, honey.  A little oak and char.  Full and rich.

Smooth and Sweet, this Whiskey lacks oomph. You can really run a magnifing lens over what the Wheat Brings to the mashbill. Palate has Vanilla Pudding, almost like tapioca, and a faint honey note. The nose is well finished but ephemeral, hinting at what this could become with a little more time in the barrel. This is pleasant and delicate, yet could be more assertive. It is reminicent of an Irish Whiskey, in its light, unobtrusive profile.
Strong fire-side flavor, decent for sipping.
Totaly different than I expected.  Strong vanilla sweetness.
Smells like burn but drinks nice. Novice whiskey drinker so it's better over ice.

My first wheat whiskey.  Definitely smoother and gentler than the traditional corn or rye based, but not as complex or full of character as some of the barley based single malts.  Overall, a really easy sipping, great for a lazy hot Saturday afternoon.  Really can't go wrong for the price either---just over $35.
Good upfront wheated bourbon with loads of flavor.    Finishes in a very unique fashion with a large oak flavor.  Unique and easy to drink.
Smooth, good wheat flavor and clean but nothing terribly crazy. Perfectly enjoyable glass.

Nose is mild, with hints of fresh bread dough, vanilla, and a bit of alcohol burn. Palate starts off very smooth and decently rich, with vanilla, honey, and light brown sugar, and then goes pretty much nowhere.  The finish is smooth and very slightly dry, with a floral hint at the very end.  This juice is incredibly one-note, and while it's an interesting change of pace from everything else, it just doesn't have enough to keep me interested past the first sip.  The closest comparison I can think of is a very, very light Irish, (Knappogue is a good example) but without the light fruit, and far fewer floral notes.  Worth trying once, but not what I'm looking for in my dark spirits.

Awful smell that resembles rubbing alcohol. Decent taste, though, that fortunately doesn't have the characteristics of the smell. A lot of spice, though, which I like, just not sold on full wheated whiskies, yet.

Wheat, caramel, corn are the main aromas.  Arrives on the palate light and sweet and soft.  Leaves the palate with hints of black pepper and oak. Easy sipping for the hot summer days.  Simple and easy. A decent dram. [85/100][Tasted: 8/12/15]
Vanilla, caramel, banana bread, red hots on the nose. Sweet, slightly spicy, good.
Not super flavorful and a little harsh.
Light bourbon. Orange zest tangy. Sweet of honey well balance finish  little hints of cinnamon back end..nice

Had this at a party a few weeks ago. I don't think the bar tender was to impressed, as he had to get a step ladder to reach the bottle, which looked as if it was unopened. Had on 1 ice cube. Incredibly smooth, exactly like the original review. I'll have to buy a bottle for home.
Very soft and sweet, almost like honey has been added. Very pleasant, it strikes me as something I might use to get friends who "don't like whiskey" into whiskey.
Smooth; wheat bread, and baking spices in this beverage. Excellent tingle on the finish. Very interesting. Like Maker's 46 without the burn. Need me a bottle of this juice.
Honey butter sweet in taste and texture. A little peppery spice on the finish. Little to no barrel char or funk. Drink this one neat, ice kills it.

(Note that this is a review of a "Small Batch Store Select" bottle, from Kensington Wine Market in Calgary, Canada--never-mind any questions about how the hell a "Small Batch" can be store selected like a single barrel).
  
  A nice, albeit soft smell, which I guess is what to expect from a wheat whiskey; a mix of Wheaties, banana bread, slight cherry, perhaps a touch of mint and some cherry Kool-Aid powder. Vanilla cake frosting. Slight breadiness or cookie dough. Taste is--again--light, an initial soft sweetness, more bread. Slightly wheaty, light cake batter, vanilla. Something evocative of an ex-bourbon barrel Speyside Scotch. Chocolate milk powder? Honey? Somehow I get a bit of cornmeal or cornflour despite the absence of corn from the mash. A touch of banana esters. Finish is a bit hot, dry. Slight vanilla and wood char. Nougat, maybe? Not terrible, but aggressively mild in flavour (aside from big, surprising heat in the finish). Super mellow, even without ice or water. Perhaps a nice warm-day summer sipper by the campfire, but there's not enough here to keep the attention of a whiskey fan.
Smooth and sweet. I agree with another reviewer - drink this neat as it falls apart with ice.
Sweet and hot but still goes down easy. Coats the mouth with a nice honey finish. A bit of pineapple and caramel on the nose.

Nose - Interesting nose on this one. I get a light buttery vanilla caramel, buttercotch. Hint of dried pineapple or the white pineapple life savers. Hint of brown sugar. Definitely a sweet nose.
Taste - Thin but buttery mouthfeel. Vanilla, faint cinnamon spice, brown sugar and clover honey.
Finish - Relatively short, slightly bitter oak, the pineapple on the nose makes its appearance here, but very faintly.
78/100

Woody toned color, with a tinge of orange.  Sweet floral tones, orange, candy apple, and almonds on the nose.  The taste comes off as slightly nutty, and then strolls along the tongue revealing juicy candy notes. It reminds me of gummy worms and cherry fruit snacks. The finish is engages more gushy fruit snacks and spice.  This whiskey is definitely candy!  Easy drinking that I would recommend for beginners and the casual drinker. I wouldn't even bother with water or ice.
Acquistapace Barrel select pick for $26 on 07.01.16
Has an age statement, smooth, solid flavor.   What more can you ask for?   Really better than most wheated bourbons on the market.
Very strong and odd flavor. All wheat, no complex. Makes me want to sneeze. Taste like grass that's been toasted with tobacco.
A little hotter than I expected but I get the sweetness. More honey than candy. Somebody mentioned banana bread. I get the spice part of that but not the banana. Fairly easy to drink. I like this.
C&B 8/16. All wheat American whisky. Sweet arrival, spicy aftertaste. $30
First time to try and it great!  39 bucks!
Surprisingly good for the low price point.
Love wheated bourbons and this one is great. Smooth and sweet with a warm spicy finish. Great sipper.
Sweet vanilla, some mild oak that disappears with a drop off water, a honeyed finish that doesn't

Wheat is pretty smooth at the start but this has a massive burn on the tail. Sweetness is honey, with a little clove spiciness, some fruit preserve and a little bit of green apple. Aroma is also honey with esters of candy sugar and vanilla. At this price point this is incredibly serviceable.
A little too sweet from the honey otherwise good spice and burn slowly building up in the chest
A very smooth wheat Kentucky whiskey like a finer bourbon but not a true bourbon.
Good taste overall. Smooth. Little burn
Maybe try at a bar before buying

A smooth, lightly toasted whiskey, easy to pick up vanilla and a subtle sweetness like honey. I pick up a little burn or alcohol forward feel that settles with a bit of water, or a few sips in. It is worth sipping as the flavors of oak and the malt from the wheat come out if you let it roll over your palate. It really grew on me over the night.

Mild vanilla nose. Mild honey & oats flavor. Sweet oats finish that lingers.
Distilled in new charred oak barrels, distilled at less than 160 proof with no coloring, flavoring or blending agents. Mashbill: 51% red winter wheat,  37% corn & 12% malted barley.

I was so much looking forward to this one. I had determined that I like wheated bourbons over high rye bourbons. I thought "the more wheat the better". Well, maybe not. 

I really wanted to love this one, but I didn't. I just didn't care for it. I'll finish the bottle, but I won't return. There are several other that cost less that I like a whole lot more.
Bought this in Kentucky. It was good! Smooth without too many crazy spices. Sweet. Honey flavors.

Nice wheated bourbon. 

Just over a 3.5 for me.

$52 90 in Ontario
Very easy to drink. Slightly sweet with some spice notes.
A good sweet flavor with, as well, a good, coated burn in the throat

Sweet honey and vanilla on the nose. Caramel, honey and vanilla taste overshadowed by a flat, one-dimensional alcohol taste. A bit spicy on the tongue and hefty spice, borderline burn, going down. A bit of water does not help.
A bit boring, malty, and one dimensional.
Molasses, some spice, oak and burnt toast all present.  Almost worthy of 4 stars, sweetness can be somewhat overpowering.
Best wheat whiskey for the price.  Hands down.

Light, inviting, Carmel on the nose. First sip is a little hot /peppery. Second sip is much smoother with sweeter butterscotch notes with a repeating pepper/oaky finish. For the $30 price range it’s well priced. Would choose makers over this for a wheated bourbon.

The nose initially had a pretty sweet vanilla aroma, with some general cereal sweetness

Taste has a lot of bready flavors honey, and very very mild spice. There’s an Apple/pear thing too. 
Adding a bit of water gives way to more fruity notes

The finish is very clean, with little lingering flavors. 

This whisky was part of a tester set I got, and is a nice surprise. I was expecting this to be merely okay, but I really dig this.

I thought it would taste different than your average bourbon but I don’t find that it does. Less corn than average but it’s still the corn sweetness I recognize, along with dry oak and floral spice. I get the wheat but it doesn’t stand out to me. Considering the profile I get I’ll stick to wheated bourbon. $53 in Ontario.

$39.99 @ TW. 
For the price this is a pretty solid wheater. Soft vanilla and brown sugar upon entry. Mid pallette feature sweet oak and some orange peel. Finish is more vanilla , toffee and oak. Medium finish and a bit drying, however, it's balanced. Over a nice change of pace from traditional Bourbon's without straying too far. 3.5/5

Very smooth and great flavor. The wheat mellows and blends the flavors. corn sweet, some fruit and a touch herbal before a sight warming in the back. After a few sips floral flavor comes out. Going to look for a bottle!

Really good wheat forward whiskey has great flavor lots of oak and sweet wheat and some spice on the pallet at 7 years old and 90 proof this whiskey is a bargain at 29$ I would pay 50$ this is from Heaven Hill Distillery
Light notes of honey, vanilla, and toast. The alcohol had a tendency to overpower the flavors.
3.7ish. Pretty good. It’s no Weller but what is really?

Very mild nose.  Vanilla-pear torte if you can catch much of anything. Maybe a touch of underripe banana.

Not much taste at first, then develops a surprising oaky iodine with a little burn neat.  Very sweet, the burn would be gone with just a little water, leaving only vanilla sweetness.  Rich and toasted cereal grain.  A thin buttered toffee.

Gentle heat on the finish.  Slightly bitter, but not off-putting.  I do get a bit of the characteristic Heaven Hill peanut essence there at the back end.

Nice.  Not sure if I prefer it to Makers or Wellers, but not sure I don't either.  Easily worth a try for < $30.
Very balanced and warm in the throat.  Not as thin tasting as other whiskeys.  Well done!
Nice whiskey. It is smooth and had a nice sweetnesses. Adding the finish to me it’s like eating a slightly sweet cinnamon stick.

Have had this before, but I had to try this again after having the Parker's Wheat. Actually, the nose is similar. Obviously not as intense, but ish. And pleasant in its own right. Deep honey. On the palate, it starts off like the Parker's but that ends pretty quickly, and likewise the finish is short. There's a similar honey note, but this definitely is not as intense or deep, and unfortunately it's more bitter than I was expecting. It feels creamy. There's a hint of vanilla on the nose but none on the palate. Some herbal notes. Bravo for the addition of an age statement, but this seems younger than 7 years. I understand this is going to suffer in comparison to the Parker's, but I think even if I hadn't had the Parker's front of mind, I wouldn't be thrilled with this. 6/27/18

Nose: On the nose I get immediately the charred oak from the barrel interior, a nice macho whiff to start the drink off right. As it has time to stretch it's legs in the glass for a bit (Ha) I also get dandelion and wildflowers along with vanilla ice cream, and randomly carrots. It's a delightful bouquet, no arguments from me!

Taste: The palate starts sweet and friendly with honey. Notes of grain cereal like Chex or Crispex stand out. And (country folks may get this more) you know when you're walking outside and you pick a dry stalk of grass to put in your mouth? There's that taste: a grassy / straw in your mouth taste. And there is no finish to speak of unfortunately.

Opinion: You know, I don't see many wheat whiskies. Bernheim claims to be the first, so well done there! I think this dram isn't challenging at all except maybe for the slightly higher alcohol content (45 abv), but dang! It has some complexity alongside the friendliness that I can see making this a good dram to have paired with a pipe on a nice night and a few good friends shooting the breeze. Cheers!

Very nice whiskey.  It is smooth but deceivingly hot and spicy. Very buttery and toasty.  Toasted oat is a prevailing taste. Think Honey Nut Cheerios for the really grown up!  I am not a fan of typical assertive boubons with smokey undertones or finishes.  I am not a rye fan either so this fits the bill nicely!  Really good stuff. Only $24.95 in NC for the month of June 2018. What a deal.
Tasted at Dan Murphy's Whisky night
Not bad. 3.5. Its a little harsh!
light, little bite, not overly flavorful but great for sipping

Wow, why haven't I tried this sooner? Sophisticated and complex spiciness both on the nose and palate. Long finish of some sort of licorice candy that I have never tasted before. Oddly, it makes a pretty good Manhattan too. A steal at 7 years old and only $26!
Nose of Carmel. Tastes of sweetness and vanilla and not much else.

on the first sip I can taste the sweetness of the drink, notes of vanilla, warm bread, a somewhere in there are floral notes. I purchased this while it was on sale, saw that it was labeled as being a small batch, amd so I took a shot... not ny favorite, and probably not on my shelf again. Not bad, just didn't do it for me.

American whiskey tasting evening, Sydney, 21 September 18. Whiskey #1

Nose: Fragrantly floral, vanilla essence, pine resin, honey and buttery notes, cereal grains and some oaky toffee.  Adding water brings out some rather leaden brown sugar and tends to collapse the nose.
    
    Palate: A full spicy arrival with some mild sweet ginger and bitter orange marmalade. A fruity note, a little nuttiness and some grassy, minty flavours. Water makes the palate harder rather than softer, amplifying the spicy notes too far and unbalancing the whiskey.
    
    Finish: Medium/long. Toasted cereal, bread and some woody notes.
    
    Generally speaking it has a soft and approachable character, but it's not as sweet as some comparably priced bourbons can be. The character is dry and it's softer on the nose than the palate, which turns woody as it develops.
    
    There's a cantankerous spicy note running through it that is both an asset and a fault. It lends complexity and interest, but it's a simple aroma/flavour that becomes too dominant if water is added. I'd recommend taking this whisky neat.
    
    I tasted this as the first whiskey in a flight of six at a liquor store tasting evening, and it was a great starter. I came back to the glass throughout the tasting and it held up pretty well against the following (much better) drams, although by the end of the evening its simplicity was becoming obvious.
    
    At the price in Australia this is just barely value for money, but it's definitely worth a try at least once. It rates a solid 3 stars and I might even buy a bottle some day if I find it on special ... but not today.
    
    "Good" : 3.5 stars
Surprisingly good, little bite but sweet and rich
another great 100% wheat whiskey. reviewer called it as it is. worth keeping in stock
Sweet, fruity, spicy, wood. In that order.

Nose - Freshly baked bread, vanilla, rye, honey and fresh fruit. 

Palate - Sweet with vanilla, cooked sugar, brown sugar, honey, oak and toast. 

Finish - Long and warm with cinnamon, vanilla, brown sugar and baking spices.
Very smooth drinker.  Sweet, honey notes.  No rough edges.  Would definitely buy again.  This is a great any day whiskey.
Soft and sweet. Good for what it is.
One of my favorite, non-scotch whiskies for under $30.00. Much like bourbon. Similar to Elijah. Smooth, vanilla and apple. Nothing to remarkable. I agree with the distiller.com profile on this one.
The more I sit on it, the whiskey is so smooth it’s deceivingly good. Smells great but the flavor doesn’t last long. Good above average pour.

Sweet nose of cereal and corn. Sweet up front with spice on the front of the tongue. There is a floral note in there but I can’t pinpoint which. Oak is mild to medium and I’m surprised how smooth this went down. Not the complexity of a bourbon, no nuances or hidden surprises, but very enjoyable. I’m reminded of a simpler Jefferson perhaps.
Hot aroma, sweet, actually liked this better neat than on ice
Caramelly, on the sweeter side, but still has a gnarly burn even watered down.
Not my cup of tea. Not a wheated whiskey fan and this one is definitely sharp. Thanks for sharing though Mike!
it's decent, just not much going on here. little bit of sweetness, get some oak. just a boring whiskey. wouldn't buy again.
Figuring out that Weller really found the perfect recipe; wheat isn’t just a magic bullet.

Even though it’s a wheat whiskey I get very sweet caramel corn on the nose. Palate is medium bodied, hot, and full of sugar. Getting some very sweet toffee toward the end. Most of the notes remind me of shitty corporate candy. Some water brings out nougat flavors and maybe fruit cake. Not a huge fan of the sugary shitty candy notes.
Solid for the cost, will keep this stocked on my shelf as a daily drinker. Sweet and smooth, easy to drink neat.
Smooth and easy drinking. I get sweet cherries and vanilla in the nose. Has a sweet flavor that is reminiscent of cream soda.
very smooth, especially on rocks, sweet with a spicy burn at the end. very good house whiskey for a decanter at home.
Very fruity with a soft initial bite... the warmth lingers... unique taste that is very sweet... Interesting.
Some of the best bourbon is cheap. This is sooo close to perfect!!

I am reluctant to give anything under a 3 especially a 7 age bottle but his has some funky taffy medicinal with a lot of alcohol on the nose when neat.  Burn is instant and has some funky flavors like medicinal with some overly sweet notes.  I wanted to like this one but man it’s just not my bag.
It good but really peppery on the back end
this is not nearly as good as it used to be

Nose: Sweet caramel, butterscotch, oak & wheat.

Taste: Big body, thick butterscotch, wheat grain, and sweetness. Not too sweet because the Proof is high enough to carry the drink forward. 

Finish: Lingers for a bit...nice and rounded like wheat toast.
Yuk. Has some off taste of sweet tea mixed with vanilla. Is quite thin and just gross.  I wanted to like this one but it’s clearly not bourbon. Closer to fireball minus the cinnamon. Gross

Wheated bourbon nose indicative of a Heaven Hill product. Smooth across the profile with a small spike on your exhail. Vanilla to start, moving to a light pine. The finish makes this bourbon. Extremely refreshing on a big rock."
Interesting flavor profile. Irish whiskey lovers, especially lower malt, grain whiskey, might enjoy this one.

Tasted as part of a flight of Devils River, Breakers Bourbon, Elijah Craig Small Batch, and Bernheim Wheat Whiskey.

Nose:
Had to go deep to get a good nose on this one. Slight caramel and vanilla notes.
2nd nose similar - had to go deep to get anything.

Tasting:
Actually better than I was prepared for with the nose. Ranks at top of the 4, with the Elijah Craig small batch. Smooth, full, with a decent finish, but not overly long. Good wheated bourbon profile, easy to enjoy neat. Slightly oily in mouth. I would add this one to my collection.

I get lots of sweet cereal on the nose almost like Cheerios vibe mixed with some Heaven hill distinct peanut funk. Imagine larceny on steroidsssss! The mouthfeel is decent about as much as to be expected on something 45% so a bit thin, but I’m a proof whore if being honest! 
The whole vibe is okay smooth with just hints of bitter tannic if even. Like with larceny with thrown on the rocks it’s super sweet and easy to drink
The wheat makes it sweet... or at least that rhymes. Liked it more than I thought. Would drink again as a daily drinker.
Light and balanced, some mild honey and flowers; good value for the money

Nose... Chocolatey cereal, oats, and overall very nutty..

Appearance... From dark copper to a light mahogany this Wheater displays it's seven years...

Taste... From rich and creamy, to coffee and smoke there's plenty going on. The finish lasts longer than you'd imagine, and stays with long after you've taken a pull...

Overall... For the simple fact that it's just so so easy to sip upon, offering heat, nuance, such sweetness and a soft mouth feel it's truly enjoyable...

This was one of the first brown spirits I purchased, so my first review is fairly primitive (though still accurate). Thought I'd re-review a little more in-depth. 
APPEARANCE: Pours into the Glencairn a light copper color and develops skinny, fast moving legs after a quick swirl.
NOSE: Dry, dry, dry. Dry wheat toast. Dry grass. Dry, dusty oak. There is a sweet sugary note in the background that just eludes description. It borders on floral and reminds me a bit of wildflower honey? The longer it is in the glass, the more prominent it becomes... and the more crazy it drives me that I can't identify it.
NEAT: Thin mouthfeel. Comes in sweet with Vanilla and Honey. A hint of Coca-Cola, maybe? A good dose of oak. Slightly hot and finishing with bitter oak notes and mint clinging to the palate. I occasionally get a hint of cocoa.
SPLASH: Really ups the sweetness. The Cola note is definitely there now. Still a touch bitter on the finish, but less so. The dark chocolate really is more assertive on the finish as well.
VERDICT: An excellent whiskey! Not the most complex, but I really enjoy it. I'm at a loss as to why I haven't had it in so long. Bernheim is delicious in a rocks glass with a large cube. Sweet and Oaky with a definite chocolate note on the finish. This could definitely be a summer time sipper. Kudos to Heaven Hill for this unique age-stated product. I would love to see special releases of this in the future. Single Barrel? 10 Year? Cask Strength? Store Picks? So, Heaven Hill, if you're listening.......
Sweet and smooth with a couple rocks
A small taste of toffee with a little spice!
oddly, I like it better than most wheated Bourbons, which I tend to dislike
Sweet vanilla and honey on the nose, a unique palate of berries, light toffee and spearmint. A kick of heat on the finish, then a pleasant warmth.

Sweet cherry note on first sniff, almost candy like. Stays on into following sniffs. Reminds me of something I can't place the smell.
Lovely sweet taste with smokey leather flavor half way through. The woody flavor is not super strong, and the type of tree is not evident.
Little bit spicy towards the finish but not super strong. Pleasant spice stays on tip of tongue.

Adding 4 drops of water tones down the sniff but still pleasant. Flavor and notes are muttled but very pleasant still.

Absolutely favorite bourbon under $30 in North Carolina.
Good Wheated whisky. Sweet with vanilla and nice oak and char flavor. Small bite. Opens well with water which mellows the burn. Good whisky though may be a bit pricy.
Better for mixing than on ice.
Been looking this for a while and glad I found it! Dangerous stuff with an ice cube as I can barely taste the alcohol. Quickly becoming one of my favorites.
Absolutely delicious. Don’t tell the retailers but it’s very underrated and undervalued. Smooth and sweet. Will buy again!

Goes down neat and very smooth.  
I would try it for sure. a nice Rye .
Toast and iodine on the nose, smooth vanilla on the palate, warm medium finish
Small goblet, neat, at home.  Sweet nose, some vanilla and wood chips.  Very sweet and smooth, very drinkable.  No wow factor, but solid.  5/25/19

In a world where age statements are becoming increasingly scarce, Heaven Hill sticks to solid numbers for many of their whiskies.  This one is a 7-year product.  Notice how I haven't called it a bourbon?  It's not.  It's a whiskey composed largely of wheat, breaking the rule that bourbon must be 51% corn.  To its credit, that big change in mash bill produces a dramatic difference in its flavors.  It's incredibly sweet and filled with "high-register" flavors, if that makes any sense.  It's almost icy in its profile, with a chilled citrus flavor that's reminiscent of orange popsicles and ice cream.  The age comes through in a wood-cabinet varnish accent that helps give this some tannic grip.  There aren't many dark, brooding bourbon flavors here, but it works pretty well.
Ultra smooth first hit with a tingle on the edges of the tongue.  Good flavor but not as full as a fine bourbon might have.

Bernheim Original Wheat Whiskey is the first new style of American whiskey since prohibition.  The mashbill must consist of 51% wheat.  The mashbill for Bernheim Original Wheat Whiskey is 51% wheat, 37% corn, and 12% barley.  From what I can find, there are only a handful of wheat whiskey’s out there.  This one does have a 7 year age statement on the bottle which is a plus now days.  The color is a nice amber color.  The legs are thin but do not run to fast down the glass and after a while the just cling there.  The nose is sweet with lots of vanilla, caramel, and honey.  The taste is vanilla, caramel, some oak, and a touch of spice.  The finish is fast with hints of oak with a slight residual caramel sweetness.  It is very light and easy to drink whiskey. This would be a great choice into whiskey for someone new. To me this is very similar to other wheated bourbons.

Nose: sweet caramel, cherries 
Palate: sweet, caramel, spice, oak
Finish: syrup, spice, tobacco/leather on back end

The ethanol pokes right through throughout. Tasting notes from Distiller say heavily toasted bread, vanilla, and oak spice. Dead on. Soft caramel comes through as I drink it more, but that ethanol is still sticking its head up. Disproportionately sharp for a 45%. Last sip had some good amylose finally, but man that alcohol is in the finish.
Sweet, smooth. Very drinkable. Good with an ice cube
Super smooth.  Not full, but tasty.

If you have a friend who is hesitant to drink whiskey neat due to limited experience, this is a perfect starter. Since the market is extremely limited for wheat whiskey, I compare this to the drinkability of Maker's Mark and Larceny. All 3 are widely available and sub $30. Bernheim is smoother and lighter than either due to higher wheat, which is why I recommend it for beginners. 

Oak is most prominent on the nose, due to the 7 year statement. I also smell caramel, but keep in mind everything I'm smelling is subtle. The taste is equally light. All of the flavors I see in reviews are mild at best, including the oak and alcohol. This whiskey basically disappears on the tongue. I barely know I had a sip of it 10 seconds after swallowing. It is honestly impressive how light and drinkable a 7Y whiskey can be. But that's not what I want these days. I see value in this, especially for $29 with its age statement and uniqueness. However, it is boring to drink and I'm having a hard time finishing the bottle because I always want to reach for something else. Buy this for your friend who drinks whiskey on the rocks or Crown Royale straight, I'm sure they'll enjoy this.

Strong caramel nose.  The palate has a strong caramel flavor - it's also got a sharp bite of spice, far spicier than I was expecting from a wheat whiskey.  It has a sharp black pepper bite.  It feels a bit thin for my taste, but it's a  pleasant and easily drinkable whiskey at a pretty reasonable price.  The finish is dry with a bid of astringent woodiness along with some cereal notes.  This isn't particularly complex but it's enjoyable for a change of pace.
It’s a fine little whiskey, soft & smooth but it lacks a whole lot of character. Nose is a little floral followed by a light honey flavor. It’s not bad but is just so lacking.

Oak, vanilla caramel
 It thin this would be better if it aged longer.
OK. Doesn't do much for me.Will not be buying again.
Added a couple dashes black walnut bitters for fun
Very solid wheated with a great price point.
Nice a surprisingly complex. An 88 in my book

Oh the rabbithole a person can go down when trying to trace history of a particular whiskey!
What we have here is Bernheim Original Kentucky Straight Whiskey Aged 7 Years.
On the nose there is brown sugar and vanilla sweetness with citrus and blackberry. On the palate you get the same flavors with cinnamon, oak, and candied orange peel as well as wheat toast. Medium finish with black pepper, burnt sugar, and more toasted bread. This is something different versus the usual bourbon and rye that is coming out of Kentucky and is much appreciated.
The history behind the label is a bit tangled and takes some research to unravel. Bernheim Original was first released in 2005 with the 7 Year expression sometime after. The label is actually owned by Heaven Hill and is distilled at the Bernheim Distillery that Heaven Hill acquired in 1999 from Diageo along with it's DSP-KY-1 permit. This was the result of a fire in 1996 at Heaven Hill's original facility in Bardstown that almost completely destroyed their plant (DSP-KY-31) and about 90,000 barrels of aging bourbon. Jim Beam and Brown-Forman stepped up and helped Heaven Hill to use their capacity to continue to produce until 1999 when they acquired Bernheim Distillery in Louisville and now all production for Heaven Hill occurs there. Aging, bottling, and shipping is all done at the Bardstown location.

Here goes, hoping for a little bit more characters than the Woodford wheated whiskey. The body is pretty thin and the legs are pretty quick. Color is a medium amber.

The nose honestly doesn’t offer me much. I might get a little lightly toasted oak and green apple.

The first sip is pretty smooth, but also pretty bland.  The flavor is almost bittersweet in a way. The second sip brings around a little bit more leather and caramel with maybe a little bit of raisin in the background? Still no burn, and no spice as one might expect with a wheated whiskey.

Revisited this last night with my father in law.  He like it, which is generally a bad sign.  Actually chewing on it I got a LOT of smoke and char this go round.  I missed it at first - probably cuts any sharper oak flavors to keep it smooth but gives it an unbalanced funk that doesn’t play as well with the lighter grain notes.

Still don’t love it but wish I did.  Gimme Larceny any day over this one as it layers much better (still not saying much).
Enjoyable.  Honey, toast and oak from the nose to the palate.   The finish is medium-short.  It's a typical bourbon and nothing special.  Far from the 91 Distiller gave.

It has been a while since I've had a dram so my taste buds aren't that all  tuned in to bourban. I wouldn't say this one wows me. Very sweet... mild oak, vanilla and turpintine are the predominant flavours. There is a lot better out there.
In the same field as Buffalo Trace and Larceny. Very smooth and tasty - as expected for a whiskey aged 7 years.
Minimal burn, notes of apple, caramel, and toffee
Interesting pour. Smooth, subtle creamy bread.
Alcohol, sweet, maybe cherry, smooth with water
Easy nose with a sweet mellow flavor on the back! Great price point.
It didn’t have a lot of flavor. Weller is my favorite wheated whiskey so I tried this and was not impressed
Simple but smooth. More ethanol on the nose than I’d like. Thin mouthfeel with honey bread notes. Finish was lacking a bit. A good sipper if you like wheaters, but not a whole lot going on.

Bernheim Original Wheat Whiskey is a Heaven Hill Distillery offering that launched in 2005.  It's claim to fame is being "the first new style of American Whiskey introduced since Prohibition".  I don't dabble in wheat whiskey too often, but I wanted something to compare to a recent travel pick up (Oregon Spirit Straight Wheat Whiskey; see my next review for this tasting).  It's named after the Bernheim Distillery, and by extension, Issac Wolfe Bernheim, an important player in the early Kentucky bourbon scene.  Contrary to almost everyone else in the industry, Heaven Hill first produced this wheat whiskey as an NAS offering and later added a 7-year age statement.  Cool beans.  

Mash Bill: 51% Red Winter Wheat, 37% Corn, 12% Malted Barley
Age: 7 years
ABV: 45%
Price: $29.99

Nose: Soft, light, and mellow.  Aromas of bread, light syrupy cherries, and vanilla combine to give the impression of something akin to cherry vanilla scones or cherry jam cookies alongside some faint buttery corn.  Sweet and very fruity, with a light cinnamon spice.  The ABV was so well hidden at first, you could stick your whole nose in the glass if you wanted to, but it slowly makes itself known as it opens up.

Palate: Honey sweetness and very soft.  Lots of white bread, cherry syrup, vanilla, and cinnamon, with dashes of toasty oak and corn husks.  Those could sound like fairly typical bourbon notes (minus the bread) but the light mouthfeel, simplistic profile, and straightforward delivery tell you otherwise.  It's satiny, has little astringency, and doesn't pack much heat or spice.  

Finish: Medium length.  Sweet and satiny, with a bit of cinnamon spice heat.  In a surprising turn, the barrel char and oak hangs on the longest, but it doesn't veer into unpleasant, over-oaked territory.  

Overall Impressions: This dram doesn't scream character.  In fact, it's so softly spoken, it doesn't scream much of anything.  It's like the economical Macallan 12 of wheat whiskey.  But if you're in the mood for something light, mellow, and very easy to sip, it does offer good VFM for a 7-year age statement whiskey for under $30.  I'm fairly certain I would reach for this over the similarly-priced Woodford Reserve Bourbon (sorry for picking on you Woodford, I'm just finding you too musty lately).  

With the exception of the soft mouthfeel (even then, I'd call Berheim's 'satiny' and Oregon Spirit's 'velvety'), this is different enough from the Oregon Spirit Straight Wheat Whiskey I'm trying it alongside, it almost feels a bit unfair to compare them. However, I did have an easier time scoring this dram, probably because it didn't stand apart so much.

3.25 ~ 78 ~ Average

Lighter color than bourbon? Aroma has fruit - peach, banana up front. Then licorice.  Flavor is "hot" though, some licorice on the finish, not particularly sweet.  Wait actually on the second sip some sweetness does appear before disappearing behind the heat. Interesting.
Starts easy, finishes with a kick

Nose - sweet grain, barrel spice, rye, caramel and a bit of dried green herbs
Taste - Barrel and rye spice up front, some cinnamon and buttery caramel come through, it’s a nice combination of sweet and spice 
Finish - the spice fades quickly and you’re left with a burnt caramel sweet ness and a little bit of heat
Heaven Hill has never and most likely will never disappoint me with their whiskeys.
Floral nose; smooth, warm, butterscotch and honey on the palette.
Smooth, strong burnt wood smell, toasty
Very light clover honey color, soft aroma on the palate, sweet initial taste, mid palate adds a little complexity, very little heat or spice. I enjoyed this as a very smooth casual sipper.

Bread and butter on the nose, soft fruit and spice on the taste, and a sharp "crisp" with the finish. A good bit barrel spice but you don't get it at all on the nose. Pretty great, hope more wheat whiskey's will be made.

Color: dark gold

Aroma: sweet fruit and hay.

Taste: grain forward with sweet citrus fruits gaining momentum by sip 3. 

Finish: short, light, sweet.
Not bad on the nose. Full mouth feel. Way too much heat and long finish for my taste. Not a big fan

Subtle, lite, well rounded, nothing jumps out sharply taking over the show. Beautiful golden color. Nose has yeast and crusty bread notes. Taste also has bread notes with vanilla wafers. Aftertaste has a nice slow mild cinnamon burn. I think this will be a yearly purchase.
My first wheat whiskey. Delicious! Sweet, rich, raisin

Nose is fruit and fresh baked bread.  Those tastes are there on the palate along with honey and orange peel.  Finish is medium length and sweet.  Very enjoyable and a great value that you can actually find on the shelf!  If you prefer low rye and wheated bourbons this is one to try.

I'm really struggling to pick up much when nosing this one. Very mild notes of cherry, almost undetectable. Right up front is a peppery rye that's quickly overwhelmed by wheat. It starts off with a raw grain flavor and develops into buttery wheat toast. Fairly smooth finish with a little campfire smoke at the end.
Good, but I was expecting a bit more depth

Tossing this into the category of undrinkable neat - light on the flavor, astringent, ethanol overwhelms what little flavor exists. Bought a bottle in 2014, wanted to like this, but it’s my most regrettable purchase - not a sipper, only good for mixing.

Part of the blind advent calendar. Revisiting and using a mix of my notes from blind and now that I know what it is.
Nose is light baking spice, eucalyptus, some sweet oak, and light nostril burn.
Taste is caramel forward with light baking spices and some floral notes.
Medium finish with toasty oaky caramel and some light drying nutiness.
Enjoyable.
Full and sweet. Smooth and delicious. Good everyday

Pour is brassy. Some legs and sheeting.

I'm not impressed with the nose. A bit thin. Hot. A touch of acetone over a sweet note. 

Tastes like grass. Dry, brown, autumn grass. It's not unpleasant though. Notes of dry corn husks, and a dusty September field. 

Not my jam.
Not enough experience to really say. Sweet, not spicy. Easy sip neat. Rocks open a lot of flavors
Reasonably smooth, mild aroma, harsh on the back of the throat but round on the top of the tongue.
Strong peanut shell and musty oak. Sweetness is there but not very complex. Flavors don’t come together for my palate.

Not much complexity on the nose.  Some oak scent with a hint of berry.  Very thin on the palate with a hint of fruit and grass.  Surprisingly there is no vanilla or baking spices that you would expect from a 7 year old whiskey. It tastes much younger with no complex notes.  Although the label states it was aged in new oak barrels,  it tastes like it was aged in a previously used barrels void of any flavors you would get from a deeply charred new oak barrel.  I would liken it to chewing on a piece of wheat straw to pass the time on a hot summer day.
Light honey aroma. Good color. Smooth aftertaste.  Not much burn.  Good mild sipping whiskey
I’ve heard this is better than Weller but I have never had Weller so I can say. This is very good though.
Nice light, sweet taste. Really good neat.  Happy Father’s Day to me.  Loving my girls today.
Nice way to drink wheat whiskey but the finish ends too quickly

Nose: honey, bread,vanilla
Palate: honey, light corn, oak spice
Finish: long finish, chocolate
Almost odorless. Taste is very mild and a little anise forward. Smooth but not my favorite.
Very smooth for a straight whiskey!  Pleasant flavors that complement my cigar..enjoy

The nose has hints of toffee, and some spice. It has legs, but the taste isn't overly oily. I am not great at identifying flavors, but I can say the balance between spice and sweetness is one of the best I have had in a while. The finish retains a hint of spice - very nice.

Pretty soft on the palette with a very short finish. It's almost gone as soon as you're done with your sip. It has all the oak you expect from a bourbon (and then some) with a little more sweetness on the front and less on the back. Overall, pretty mellow.

The nose of the bourbon features playful notes of toffee, vanilla, and toasted bread, with the slightest hint of banana.

On the tongue, this whiskey tastes sweetly of buttered toast that transitions into cask oak and vanilla.  There is a spice to the drink that enhances it and developes into the finish.  It settles into a pleasant, if mild, glow in the chest while the spice lingers on the tongue.

Excellent neat.

Light to medium color.
Slightly oily texture.
Sweet, woody, vanilla and banana nose.
Light, easy taste.  Slightly sweet.
A little bit spicy on the finish.

first wheat bourbon I have purchased. While touring Heaven Hill I had my first experience with a wheat bourbon in the form of larceny. I greatly enjoyed this so I decided to give this HH 7 year expression a shot and it was delightful!
Butterscotch and bananas on the nose, nice pepper on the front dries quickly on the tongue and leaves a light oak and horseradish finish.
Definitely sweet! Not too bad of a bite. Some burn.

I get oak and vanilla on the nose, plus something similar to clove as well.
Soft honey, vanilla, again a touch of clove then a bit of a spicy kick at the back of my throat.  Not a burn, but more of a quick spike of spice then fades quickly.   Ending a smooth slightly sweet/honey woody finish.
